summary: This is a motion filed by the co-executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate in the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands, requesting expedited approval to establish a voluntary claims resolution program (the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program) to address sexual abuse claims against Epstein. The motion outlines the proposed program's structure, administration by independent experts, and argues it is in the best interests of claimants and the estate to avoid protracted litigation. This document is a court filing and subsequent order from the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands regarding the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. The Co-Executors of the estate filed an expedited motion to establish a Voluntary Claims Resolution Program, which the court granted. The order directs the Co-Executors to submit the proposed engagement agreement for the Program Administrator and Designers under seal for court approval.

keyFacts: The co-executors of Epstein's estate are seeking court approval to create a voluntary, confidential compensation program for victims of sexual abuse, to be designed and administered by independent experts Jordana Feldman, Kenneth Feinberg, and Camille Biros.
Twelve lawsuits involving sexual abuse claims had been filed in New York state and federal courts at the time of the motion, but only one such claim had been filed in the Virgin Islands probate case.

The proposed program would be based in New York to alleviate travel burdens for claimants, would be entirely voluntary, and would allow claimants to accept or reject compensation determinations made by the independent Program Administrator.

The motion argues the program is necessary to avoid years of costly, public litigation across multiple jurisdictions and to provide a compassionate, efficient, and fair resolution process for claimants.
The co-executors request authorization to use estate funds to retain the proposed experts and to submit their engagement agreement under seal, citing its proprietary nature.
The Co-Executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate sought and received court approval to establish a Voluntary Claims Resolution Program.
The motion was filed on November 14, 2019, in Probate Case No. ST-19-PB-80 in the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands.
The court order requires the Co-Executors to submit the proposed engagement agreement for the Program Administrator and Designers under seal for court approval.
The legal team representing the Co-Executors is from the firm Kellerhals Ferguson Krobian PLLC.
Magistrate Judge Carolyn P. Hermon-Percell granted the motion, indicating judicial oversight of the estate's administration process.
